ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This is a great course. I love the high faculty-to-student ratio and ability to truly discuss papers with professors and other students, not simply to take the prof's viewpoint as in a lecture. The course suffered a bit this semester from the lower-than-usual faculty involvement, but that is unusual.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Durland Fish  Dr. Fish did a good job with the course since it seems to have been handed to him totally and unexpectedly. The course did suffer a bit from having the attention of fewer people--we were a speaker short, and two were from Yale, which was a bit disappointing. And there was a little too much vector-borne disease for me. But I realize this was not Dr. Fish's fault and was unusual for him and the course.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Highly recommended. It's important to be able to interact with faculty as an equal, and this course is a great place to learn to do so.
